entry.def: Any agent which may produce abortion.
A broad group of diseases involving unregulated cell growth. In cancer, cells divide and grow uncontrollably, forming malignant tumours, and invading nearby parts of the body.
Having the potential to cause cancer.
The treatment of cancer using specific chemical agents or drugs that are selectively destructive to malignant cells and tissues.
The treatment of cancer with one or more cytotoxic anti-neoplastic drugs as part of a standardized regimen.
Having the potential to cause disruption or breakage of chromosomes.
Detrimental or destructive to cells.
A specified quantity of a therapeutic agent, such as a drug or medicine, prescribed to be taken at one time or at stated intervals.
Having the potential to cause death of the embryo.
Causing injury to the embryo, which may result in death or abnormal development of a part due to entering the placental circulation.
A substance poisonous to the fetus.
The time required for half the quantity of a drug or other substance deposited in a living organism to be metabolised or eliminated by normal biological processes.
A substance that induces, especially a substance that is capable of activating transcription from specific genes within a cell.
Tissue death (necrosis) caused by a local lack of oxygen, due to an obstruction of the tissue's blood supply.
A substance that reduces or suppresses the activity of another substance (such as an enzyme).
Cancer of the blood or bone marrow characterized by an abnormal increase of immature white blood cells called "blasts".
Very virulent or infectious.
Medical guidelines for a medical treatment. It usually includes a treatment plan, summarized consensus statements and addresses practical issues.
The spread of a cancer from one organ or part to another non-adjacent organ or part.
A substance which may cause mutation.
The study and treatment of tumours.
The medical use of ionizing radiation, generally as part of cancer treatment to control or kill malignant cells.
A statistical process to determine detectable characteristics associated with an increased chance of experiencing unwanted outcomes.
The reactant which is consumed during a catalytic or enzymatic reaction.
Having the potential to cause congenital abnormalities or birth defects.
The degree to which a substance can damage an organism.
